data.title: Nineveh
data.text:
General Urbs 2 Featured November 22 , 2012

Nineveh (Akkadian: Ninua; Syriac: ܢܝܢܘܐ, Ninua).

Gracious Ishtar, who rules over the universe,

Heroic Ishtar, who creates humankind,

who walks before the cattle, who loves the shepherd...

Without you the river will not open

the river which brings us life will not be closed,

without you the canal will not open,

the canal from which the scattered drink

will not be closed...

Where you cast your glance, the dead awaken, the sick arise;

The bewildered, beholding your face, find the right way...

~ Prayer to Goddess Ishtar

The oldest and most populated city of the ancient Assyrian Empire, Nineveh, sat on the eastern bank of the Tigris river. The city (ancient Ninua) is first mentioned about 1800 BC as a center of worship of Ishtar whose cult was responsible for the city's early importance. A statue of the goddess was sent to Amenhotep III, Pharaoh of Egypt in the 14th century BC by orders of the king of Mitanni. Nineveh became one of Mitanni's vassals until the mid 14th century BC, when the Assyrian kings of Assur reclaimed it while overthrowing the Mittani Empire.

Nineveh's importance grew due to its central position on the main trade route between the Mediterranean Sea and Indian Ocean. Situated at the confluence of the Tigris and Khosr rivers, wealth flowed into the city from many sources, and eventually Nineveh caught the eye of neo-Assyrian monarchs. From the time of Sargon II (722-705 BC) and onward, considerable architectural expansion took place in Nineveh and it became one of the greatest of Assyria's ancient cities.

Ashurbanipal, the great king, the mighty king,

king of hosts, king of Assyria;

Son of Tukulti-Urta, the great king, the mighty king,

king of hosts, king of Assyria;

Son of Adad-nirari, the great king, the mighty king,

king of hosts, king of Assyria;

Who has conquered from beyond

the Tigris as far as Mount Lebanon

and the Great Sea*, and has brought in subjection at his feet

all the countries from the rising to the setting Sun

An inscription upon the breast of a limestone statue of Ashurbanipal, translated from the cuneiform carvings below.

* i.e., the Mediterranean Sea
